messages.subject: Re: Yoshitake wakizashi with picture of owner
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Barry I have seen the shingunto mounts where they look like the kaigunto and have the same lacquered and then sanded to show the white round nodules. But
messages.messageBody:
Dear Barry

I have seen the shingunto mounts where they look like the kaigunto and
have the same
lacquered and then sanded to show the white round nodules.

But the same on my sword has not been sanded and the lacquer totally
covers the same and you have a
nice nashiji (spelling??) surface. Makes me wonder if all of the early
shingunto have same under the
lacquer.

Have you seen a tassel with a silver star?

And why would a wakizashi be mounted in shingunto mounts?


later
david

Date: Wed, 21 Sep 2005 22:46:32 +1000
From: "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...>
Subject: Re: Yoshitake wakizashi with picture of owner

Many years ago I saw a shingunto with brown lacquered same. The blade had a
huge chip in it so I passed. I do wish now that I had bought it for the
koshirae.

More recently a friend bought a Satsuma Tadashige (Sukehiro's No. 2 pupil)
katana in a shingunto koshirae with a brown lacquered same saya. Brilliant.

I'll look at your pictures later. Congratulations, I believe it is a great
find.

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "David McDonald" <jswords@...>
To: <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, September 21, 2005 1:58 PM
Subject: [nihonto] Yoshitake wakizashi and picture of owner


Dear All

I bought a wakizashi this week. It is a 54.9 cm (21 5/8 inch)that is
bout of polish with chips in the ha (sure hope they are not to deep).

The blade is signed Heianjo ju Fujiwara Yoshitake.

There are a number of things that make this an interesting sword.

1. The shingunto mounts have been lacquered the dark green often seen
on the army mounts but this lacquer is painted over same and a
wood saya. The same is lifting way from the wood so you can
see the method of construction.
I knew that kai-gunto had lacquer over same but not shin-gunto.

Has anyone seen this type of construction on a shin-gunto?


--
David McDonald Collector of Japanese Swords and Old Iron
PO Box 265 WEB page - http://www.montanairon.com
Sidney MT 59270 email - jswords@...
406-482-3243 evenings I do tsukamaki (wrapping of sword hilts)

Owner of White IH Cub & Super A Farmall, IH 100 & 130, 140, AC G
McD type M, Monitor, Frost King and other stationary engines.

messages.subject: Yoshitake wakizashi with picture of owner
messages.msgSnippet: Dear All I bought a wakizashi this week.  It is a 54.9 cm (21 5/8 inch)that is bout of polish with chips in the ha (sure hope they are not to deep). The blade
messages.messageBody:
Dear All

I bought a wakizashi this week. It is a 54.9 cm (21 5/8 inch)that is
bout of polish with chips in the ha (sure hope they are not to deep).

The blade is signed Heianjo ju Fujiwara Yoshitake.

There are a number of things that make this an interesting sword.

1. The shingunto mounts have been lacquered the dark green often seen
on the army mounts but this lacquer is painted over same and a
wood saya. The same is lifting way from the wood so you can
see the method of construction.
I knew that kai-gunto had lacquer over same but not shin-gunto.

Has anyone seen this type of construction on a shin-gunto?

2. There is a silver (silver like) metal star on the tassle. I have
never seen anything attached to tassles.

Has anyone seen a star on a tassle? What might it mean???

3. When I went to pick up the sword. The wife of the gave me a picture.
She said that her late husband did not talk much about his time
during WWII but she pointed to the person standing in the back
row to the right (looks like army uniform) and said that was
the owner of the blade.

CAn anyone translate what is written on the back of the picture?

You can see images at

http://www.montanairon.com/swords.html

then click on #7 Images to view and it will the the top sword.

Thanks for any help.

later
david (I plan to post this on a couple of email lists)




--
David McDonald Collector of Japanese Swords and Old Iron
